abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The sodium (Na<jats:sup>+</jats:sup>):multivitamin transporter (SMVT), encoded by <jats:italic>SLC5A6</jats:italic>, belongs to the sodium:solute symporter family and is required for the Na<jats:sup>+</jats:sup>-dependent uptake of biotin (vitamin B7), pantothenic acid (vitamin B5), the vitamin-like substance α-lipoic acid, and iodide. Compound heterozygous <jats:italic>SLC5A6</jats:italic> variants have been reported in individuals with variable multisystemic disorder, including failure to thrive, developmental delay, seizures, cerebral palsy, brain atrophy, gastrointestinal problems, immunodeficiency, and/or osteopenia. We expand the phenotypic spectrum associated with biallelic <jats:italic>SLC5A6</jats:italic> variants affecting function by reporting five individuals from three families with motor neuropathies. We identified the homozygous variant c.1285 A > G [p.(Ser429Gly)] in three affected siblings and a simplex patient and the maternally inherited c.280 C > T [p.(Arg94*)] variant and the paternally inherited c.485 A > G [p.(Tyr162Cys)] variant in the simplex patient of the third family. Both missense variants were predicted to affect function by in silico tools. 3D homology modeling of the human SMVT revealed 13 transmembrane helices (TMs) and Tyr162 and Ser429 to be located at the cytoplasmic facing region of TM4 and within TM11, respectively. The <jats:italic>SLC5A6</jats:italic> missense variants p.(Tyr162Cys) and p.(Ser429Gly) did not affect plasma membrane localization of the ectopically expressed multivitamin transporter suggesting reduced but not abolished function, such as lower catalytic activity. Targeted therapeutic intervention yielded clinical improvement in four of the five patients. Early molecular diagnosis by exome sequencing is essential for timely replacement therapy in affected individuals.</jats:p>

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: LR is an employee of GeneDx, Inc and PR is an employee and KMG is a director of Suma Genomics Pvt. Ltd. All other authors declare no competing interests.

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: The parents of three siblings (patients 1–1, 1–2, and 1–3 – family 1) and patient 3–1 (family 3) provided informed consent for their participation in the study, clinical data and specimen collection, genetic analysis, and publication of relevant findings. Informed consent was obtained for patient 2–1 and her parents (family 2) under a protocol approved by the Institutional Review Board of the University of Florida.
